unnormalised: ## Don't Get Dhoka-fied: Your Guide to Rental Agreements in India!
normalised: ## don't get dhoka-fied: your guide to rental agreements in india!

unnormalised: Hey folks! Finding a place in a bustling city like Mumbai or Bangalore can be a real headache, right? And once you’ve finally found that perfect PG near your office or that cool apartment with a view, there's this thing called a rental agreement staring you in the face. Don't just blindly sign it! Trust me, a little bit of due diligence now can save you a lot of headaches (and rupees!) later.
normalised: hey folks! finding a place in a bustling city like mumbai or bangalore can be a real headache, right? and once you've finally found that perfect P G near your office or that cool apartment with a view, there's this thing called a rental agreement staring you in the face. don't just blindly sign it! trust me, a little bit of due diligence now can save you a lot of headaches (and rupees!) later.

unnormalised: Think of the rental agreement as your legal *janam kundali* for your tenancy. It spells out everything! It details the rent (obviously!), but also things like the security deposit amount (Rs. 50000? Rs. 100000? Negotiate!), the lock-in period (usually 11 months, like our academic year, but check!), and who is responsible for what repairs. Imagine discovering on 15/08/1947 (okay, maybe not *that* long ago, but close enough to independence from your landlord!) that you're on the hook for fixing a leaky roof in your rented flat near IIT Delhi. Not fun, eh?

unnormalised: Make sure the agreement clearly mentions the notice period required before you can move out or before the landlord can ask you to leave. Landlords usually ask for a month (30 days) as notice period, but confirm the exact number of days. Also, read the fine print about late payment fees. Some landlords charge hefty fines for rent received after, say, the 5th of the month.

unnormalised: Pro Tip: Always get the agreement registered! It strengthens your position legally, especially if things go south (touchwood!). Think of it like getting your Aadhar card linked - makes things official.

unnormalised: And remember to review the clauses about maintenance and repairs. Does it state who pays for what if the geyser conks out at 09:00 hrs on a cold December morning? What about plumbing issues? Spell these things out clearly. Also, check if pets are allowed, if you're planning on bringing your furry friend along to your new flat near MG Road on 26/01/2024.

unnormalised: Finally, don't hesitate to ask for clarification from your landlord. It’s better to have a clear understanding upfront than to fight over something later. Happy house hunting, and may your rental agreement be as smooth as butter chicken!
